text.p: These are the leading stories in the Albanian press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.
- Armed police forces have started travelling towards the south of Albania aiming to re-establish local government institutions there.
- The Socialist Party has decided to enter elections if there is full international monitoring.
- A rebel committe in the southern town of Vlore has called on people to receive President Sali Berisha with guns and bombs if he decides to visit the town.
- Smaller parties in the nine-party interim government are upset the Socialist Party did not ask their opinion before declaring it would enter elections.
- Albania's branch of the Helsinki human rights committee said Berisha should not take part in the electoral campaign.
- The Organisation for Security and Cooperation in Europe has promised to monitor Albania's general elections in June.
- President Sali Berisha has expressed his dissatisfaction to Prime Minister Bashkim Fino over the government's demand to the international community to intensively monitor parliamentary elections.
- Italian Foreign Minister Lamberto Dini said quotes attributed to his ambassador in Tirana did not correspond to Italy's position on Albania.
- The Democratic Party said Finance Minister Arben Malaj, a Socialist, carried out political revenge when he sacked the boards of state-owned banks and the insurance institute.
- The Socialists have started their revenge on the Democratic Party administration. About 170,000 people could be sacked.
- If the Socialist Party cooperates with armed rebels in the south of the country it is a clear sign it will boycott elections on June 29.
- The Democratic Party said it never wrote documents published in the Koha Jone daily.
- Guri Durollari, the chairman of the Legality (Monarchy) Party risks being sacked because his alliance with the Democratic Party has caused many party branches to cut ties with the monarchists.
